content.raw:
We need to know what compute capabilities will be available to us on the actual AWS instance\(s\) used for CloudSim.  In particular, we currently test in such a way to mimic Nvidia TX2 systems on each drone that we fly in the simulator, meaning that we assume that the individual drones have a CPU\+GPU computer with Cuda installed.  We then build a specific version of OpenCV to support our object recognition algorithm.  As we are building our docker image, it is critical that we know what compute resources are available for each robot and what software is pre-installed on the instance.  We are also unclear on whether each robot gets its own instance or whether all robots run on a single instance.  Can you give us some insights into this and possibly specify the compute instance\(s\) from this page?

[https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/)

We need to know what compute capabilities will be available to us on the actual AWS instance(s) used for CloudSim. In particular, we currently test in such a way to mimic Nvidia TX2 systems on each drone that we fly in the simulator, meaning that we assume that the individual drones have a CPU+GPU computer with Cuda installed. We then build a specific version of OpenCV to support our object recognition algorithm. As we are building our docker image, it is critical that we know what compute resources are available for each robot and what software is pre-installed on the instance. We are also unclear on whether each robot gets its own instance or whether all robots run on a single instance. Can you give us some insights into this and possibly specify the compute instance(s) from this page?

https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/
